bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 6, 1875

div1.p: Reed reiterates his devotion to Emilie Lawrence. He describes errands in New York City and his responsibilities at Willet's Point Army Base.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 6, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Septr 6th, 1875.

div1.p:
After a day
of many disappointments, it
is a very great pleasure to
be able to sit in my rock-
ing chair &, at my leisure,
peruse your sweet letter.
At one time, I began to think
that you had forgotten to
write, or else was waiting
for the arrival of the “little
package-” Being compelled
to visit New York City,
this morning, I rode over to
Whitestone with the mail-
carrier in order to get your
letter- Of course, my heart
was light, as it always is,
when anticipating a message
from your darling, sweet
self. (Allow me to ask, by way
of parenthesis, do I use too
many words of endearment?
Although I ask, I don't expect
any answer- I only want to
say that if I were master of
ten thousand words, all express-
ing whatever is pure and love-
ly & sweet, I would write
them down & then feel chow
feebly they expressed the
inexpressible emotions of
my heart!) But to my nar-
rative -- Arriving at the P.O.
to my very great disappoint-
ment, there was no letter
for “Dr Reed,” and I was
about as sad as “love-sick
boy” could be. With a coun-
tenance, woefully elongated,
I left the office & went to
the Depot- and thence to New
York, by cars; all the way
wondering what had become
of my letter- I'm afraid, that
the remarks, I made use
of, were not very flatter-
ing to the various Post-
masters between here and
Murfreesboro. When I got
to New York, I couldn't find
the gentleman I wanted
to see & was compelled
to wait more than an hour,
at his office, before he
arrived. This was disappoint-
ment no. 2- I then paddled
my Canoe toward Fultan
Market, for the purpose of
purchasing some peaches
for our mess -- You perceive
that I am caterer for the
mess, during this month, &
hence have to superintend
the purchasing of all ar-
ticles of food- In other
words, I am the house-keep-
er, just at present- am lear-
ning, you see, so that when
you & I are ensconced in
our little cottage, I will be
able to lighten your bur-
den. Having selected a large
basketful of beautiful
fruit, I sent it by a boy
to Pier 1, from which point
our steamer leaves for this
Point- This done, I strolled
along leisurely through va-
rious streets & at last, ar-
rived at the same Pier-

To my disgust, I found that the
Seargeant, in charge of the dock,
had sent my fruit to Gover-
nors Island. Disappointment,
no. 3.! Seeing that all my
efforts came to an unlucky
termination, I immediately
embarked on board the Steam-
er for this place, feeling that
all creation was arrayed
against me! And what
has served to banish this
feeling? For I assure you,
that I am in the best of
humor, just now. It is all
owing to the fact that, on
reaching home, I found your
precious letter!

Know, my darling Emilie,
that the request you make of
me shall be complied with,
& that too, with pleasure- Don't
be afraid, my lovely little “B,”
that I will yield to the temp-
tations that may surround
me- The love which I bear
you is a sure barrier
against all of these. At the
same time, I love you yet
more for the interest which
you manifest in my be-
half- Ah! what a help it
is, in the discharge of all
my duties, to know that
there is an eye that watches
my course. God Bless you,
my own precious E, you shall
never have occasion to be
ashamed of me! Please say
to the kind person who
warned you to beware of
the Long Island damsels,
lest some one of them steal
away my heart; that I am
sorry that any one could
entertain so poor an opin-
ion of my honesty, & for my
sake, tell the person, that
were all the maidens of this
Island combined in one & that
one possessed of riches un-
numbered, I would not turn
on my heel to win her smile!
My heart has already been sto-
len by one who far surpas-
ses any thing that this Is-
land can boast of;- and
it remains with that one
to say what shall be the
disposal of that heart!
No! My darling, the more I
am thrown into the society
of other ladies, the more do I
appreciate your sterling worth.
Although there are many very
beautiful villages & resi-
dences surrounding Willet's
Point, yet, with all my heart,
can I say:

lg.l: How I long for the shade of thy groves,
Pleasure to the soul that solitude loves.
Full oft in my dreaming hours,
And feel the peace of home!

div1.closer:
Believe me, my darling,
As ever, your fond
and devoted Walter.
